section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the book and identify it as a narrative about Vincent painting his house.
Use Circle Time to introduce the vocabulary words (paint, decide).
Use Circle Time to review the letters Tt, Aa, and Mm.
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking the guiding question: How did Vincent’s house change?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Use information to describe.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Respond to instructional language.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the letters t, a, and m.
Help children sort picture names into groups that begin with the same sound.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What colors do you see in the illustrations in your book?
Can you pretend that you are going to paint your house? What do you need to start?
Can you sort these cubes by color?
Can you write a story about painting a house?
Can you use these materials to make a house of many colors?
What letter is at the beginning of the word tiger? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to build a house for Vincent?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder make plans and taking steps to a goal and introduce the vocabulary (plan, classify).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Vincent Paints His House.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Blend onset and rime.
Use information to describe.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Respond to instructional language.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children make plans in order to reach their goal of molding houses.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you act like a character from the book you’re reading?
Can you show me how you paint a house? What do you do first?
Can you count all of the colors that you know? Show the number with counters.
Can you write about a time you used paint? What did you make?
Can you use these materials to create Vincent’s house?
What letter makes the sound at the beginning of the word apple? Can you write it?
Can you build a house for one of the animals in the book? Should it be big or little? Why?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Vincent Paints His House by Tedd Arnold. Copyright © 2015 by Tedd Arnold. section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about making predictions and teach the vocabulary word (beetle).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Vincent Paints His House and asking the guiding question, Why did Vincent keep changing the color of his house?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences and predictions.
Share and celebrate written products.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Respond to instructional language.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children create stories involving the letters Tt, Aa, and Mm.
Encourage children to speak using complete sentences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the characters in your book like Vincent?
Can you pretend to be a new animal who lives in Vincent’s house?
Can you show eight counters for the eight animals in the story?
Can you write about your favorite color?
Can you use these materials to create your favorite animal from the story?
What letter makes the sound at the beginning of the word milk? Can you write it?
Can you build a house that you would like to live in? Why did you build it that way?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Vincent Paints His House by Tedd Arnold. Copyright © 2015 by Tedd Arnold. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: crayons (Lucie Lang), pencils (urfin).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: A Horse, of Course

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about creating art and introduce vocabulary (sculpt, mold).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts A Horse, of Course and Vincent Paints His House.
Read closely to make a connection with the concept question: How can we express ourselves through art?
Offer an extended play opportunity, inviting children to mold clay.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Write for different purposes.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Respond to instructional language; Make connections between words and real life.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to think of a new animal and draw a picture to show their creations.
Encourage children to use conversational etiquette.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of art is in your book?
Can you choose the color you like best?
Can you show five counters of the same color?
Can you write a story about your new animal?
Can you use some of our art supplies to make a really big snake?
Can you write the name of an animal? What are some letters in its name?
Can you build a home for your new animal?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Vincent Paints His House by Tedd Arnold. Copyright © 2015 by Tedd Arnold. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and review vocabulary (classify).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking: Why was everyone happy after Vincent painted his house?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat details in a text; Make inferences and predictions.
Write for different purposes; Share and celebrate written products.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use increasingly complex word forms.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What animal would you like to add to the story?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to share and display.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which animal in the story was your favorite? Why?
Can you pretend to be an artist? What will you use to make art?
Choose two animals from the book. How are they the same, and how are they different?
Can you write a story about painting your own house?
Can you use these materials to create a new animal for the story?
Can you use clay to make the letters A, T, and M?
Which blocks are most helpful for building houses? Why?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversation rules.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversation rules.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Blend onset and rime to form a familiar one-syllable word with and without pictorial support.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversation rules.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversation rules.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversational rules.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversational rules.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversation rules.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversation rules.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
